Award.AwardTitle: New Methods for the Synthesis of Hindered Quaternary Carbons
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Tarek Sammakia of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at The University of Colorado will explore the development of methods for the stereoselective formation of hindered carbon-carbon bonds, including all-carbon quaternary and tertiary centers. The general reaction to be developed proceeds by a cascade of cycloaddition and rearrangement reactions. This reaction is mechanistically novel, and as such studies are proposed to further elucidate the mechanism and to render it asymmetric using stoichiometric methods.

While some methods exist for the synthesis of quaternary carbons, they are limited in scope and this new method allows for the preparation of structural motifs that are not available by existing methods. The overall transformation is the equivalent of an oxidative cross-coupling of two enolates, thereby preparing 1,4-dicarbonyl compounds. There are currently no methods that directly accomplish this transformation in a stereoselective fashion bearing such hindered carbons and the major aim of this work is to provide a new and more efficient method for the preparation of this class of molecules. This will lead to a significant reduction in step-count for the synthesis of this structural motif, and the greater efficiency means less waste and fewer by-products. Successful development of this method will have an impact on many synthesis activities including the synthesis of pharmaceutical agents and new materials that bear this motif. In addition, this project will provide excellent training of undergraduate and graduate students, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences. Finally, the incorporation of these methods into undergraduate organic chemistry laboratories will be considered as this reaction is facile and cycloadditions and sigmatropic rearrangements are not commonly encountered by undergraduates.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthetic organic chemists are interested in discovering new methods of making organic molecules, and this proposal was driven by a new method of the synthesis of organic molecules bearing carbons that exist in a sterically hindered environment. The specific type of carbons addressed in this proposal are called a “quaternary” carbons, and the synthesis of such structures is intrinsically difficult. Even more difficult is the synthesis of quaternary carbons wherein the 3-dimensional arrangement of the atoms bonded to the carbon, i.e., the "stereochemistry" of the carbon, is controlled. This is what this work was able to accomplish: the stereo-controlled synthesis of quaternary carbons. The PI’s lab discovered a reaction that uses an organic functional group, called a N-vinyl nitrone, that when treated with another, called a ketene, provides a product bearing a quaternary carbon. Further, the product is obtained with high levels of stereoselectivity.

In order to render this reaction useful, a method for the synthesis of N-vinyl nitrones had to be developed as the previous method in the literature was cumbersome, lacked selectivity, and used toxic and malodorous reagents (Hg, and Se reagents). The work in this proposal led to a method that is shorter and more streamlined, produces the products with high levels of selectivity, and is applicable to a variety of molecules. In addition to developing these two methods, this project led to a third method for the synthesis of a very well established functional group, the acid chloride. This functional group is used in the synthesis of the ketene component of the key reaction, among mny other things, and most syntheses of acid chlorides proceed via a carboxylic acid. It is more convenient to handle esters, and the method developed in this research uses esters directly as precursors to carboxylic acids.

Finally, the mechanism of the key reaction to prepare quaternary carbons was studied and found to proceed via a cycloaddition followed by two rearrangements. An understanding of the mechanism of this reaction allows for the development of other reactions that also accomplish the goals of this project, and provide greater flexibility to synthetic or medicinal chemists who wish to use this method to build molecules bearing quaternary carbons.


Last Modified: 08/21/2017
Modified by: Tarek Sammakia
